But it's not just the school district that's resisting.
This is not an idea popular with the teachers' unions.

Not in just California but in other parts of the country, teachers' unions have, you know, questioned the wisdom of parent trigger laws, saying that these proves to be very divisive in the community, pitting parent against parent, parent against teacher.

They also question whether parents would be susceptible to, you know, unscrupulous charter school operators coming in and proposing changes to a school that might benefit the operator, but wouldn't necessarily benefit the students or the parent.
So there has been strong resistance from teachers' unions, to a parent trigger, certainly.
But getting back to Desert Trails Elementary, the parents seemed to have some valid complaints.

They've actually gone so far as they're already looking at bids from charter school operators, who've said that they'd be willing to help the parents transform the school.

You saw that happen in, of course, Harlem in New York, you saw it happen even in some places like the Hill District in Pittsburgh, which is actually where I grew up.
That began - some parts of that that are closer to downtown, Pittsburgh changed.
In California, in some of the hotter real-estate markets, San Francisco, even Oakland.

Actually, especially Oakland, with people spilling across the Bay Bridge from San Francisco and being priced out, moving into Oakland which had a much higher proportion of lower-income African-Americans, housing prices exploded in Oakland.
So it is East Coast-West Coast, and even in the middle of the country.
You know, there is a perception, Keith, that when an area is revitalized, that the lower-income people are in fact pushed out.
But is that in fact true?
That's true in some cases, but it really happens in a much more - I don't want to say natural, but it happens in a much more organic way in many cases.
What will happen is what I described earlier.

it's - some instances you do have a landlord that simply looks out over the terrain and says, you know, I can get a lot more money for this building if I sell it, theses condos that I can if I rent it to the people who are living here.

The more likely thing to happen is property values will rise, some early quote-unquote pioneers of neighborhoods will come in and snatch up property either because they wanted to live in the city or they like the neighborhood.
That'll force up - that'll increase prices or increase rents, because other landlords will look around and they will have a tenant just move out on their own.

That tenant will move and the landlord will say, OK, now this unit will be a condo, or this unit will have a rent that's 1,700 dollars instead of 1,100 dollars, or 1,100 dollars instead of 650 dollars.

So now the person who did - who used to occupy that unit, who was low-income, or who was African-American, or who was, you know, whatever the characteristic may have been, an identical person cannot come in and afford to then fill that housing unit.
And this happens en mass when you have the right economic conditions, which is what we saw, especially, again, during the housing boom.
What are the roles that government plays - particularly local governments, cities, municipalities, counties - in luring suburbanites back to the center of town?
They do play some role.

I mean, what you see in many cases is obviously no government is immune, and no government ignores the opportunity to get a person with a higher income, and maybe a higher net worth to live in their city, because then that means that they are able to reap some of the tax benefits, both in terms of property taxes and income taxes, and in terms of some sales taxes, especially if they have a local sales tax in place.

Just economically, the more desirable person to a city that has been hurting for money is going to be somebody who spends more money, who owns a house that costs more, and who makes more money and puts more money in city coffers.

But cities do - because many of them get money from federal housing programs, from HUD and from - through other government incentives, they, those tend to come with the responsibility on the part of the city, or the part of any municipality, to ensure that there are opportunities for equal housing, both for lower-income people.
So you will see them put in place - if the developer comes in and says, we want to build x number of units.
Well, out of x number of units, y number of units need to be, quote-unquote affordable, whatever the standard may be in that particular community.
Now, how much of a factor, if at all, is age and the age of the people who are moving in?
And how does that affect the neighborhood?

You mentioned at the very beginning of our conversation of people moving back after their kids are gone, and they don't want to drive, and they want to walk, and etc. But often-timed, we see young people moving in to the central core as well, don't we?
Yeah.
You do see young people moving into the central core.

I mean, one of the things that's interesting about the recent, quote-unquote gentrification phenomenon is that in many of these neighborhoods you are seeing a generation of African-Americans, and to large extent a generation of Latinos, who have - who previously would not have generally drawn the types of incomes, been in the types of professions that they are in, and are able to move in, and to afford things, and that creates something of a class rift, not just a race rift in some of these gentrifying neighborhoods.

I remember being in, being in Boston, in the Dorchester neighborhood, some sections of which were always heavily white, other sections of which were always staunchly black, and hearing some of the, you know, people complain about, you know, this neighborhood used to - you know, the new people who are moving in aren't like us, or the new people who are moving in was me,
(Soundbite of laughter)
I was a 20-something, single black male who made above the median income for - in that particular part of town.
I wasn't the local, I wasn't the townie, I wasn't the guy who had spent his whole life, you know, working a blue-collar job in that part of Boston.
But I could - I wanted to move to a section of Boston that quite honestly had a diverse population and had a lot of people that lived like me, and Dorchester was it.
The problem was, I didn't understand the social and economic ramifications of the people who have lived there before me, in not being able to afford it now, whereas I could.
You know, that is an interesting point you mentioned about being in a diverse neighborhood, and gentrification sort of begins the process of creating a diverse community.
But if the changes continue when one group moves in and one group moves out, it goes back to being re-segregated, doesn't it?
Gentrification can be the beginnings of a diverse community, but only if you - only to the extent that you have housing at the various points that afford people the ability to be able to move in.
Some developers are starting to understand that and take that into consideration, in terms of the long-term economic future of a development.
And some cities are starting to take that into consideration.
But you can't have just one price point that you need to be able to offer housing options in neighborhoods that fit multiple income and that fit multiple income profiles.
There are some interesting experiments going on, again, in some of these - especially in some of the cities where the housing market boomed the greatest.
In Boston I saw some interesting things going on.
New York, there have always been experiments with that.
Some of them work, some of them don't.

But again, the ability to be able to create a healthy neighborhood that is both economically stable and ethnically diverse, or diverse otherwise, is going to depend on the number of housing options that are available.
The final thing is this.

Gentrification is generally, I think, associated with whites coming into an area that is either black or brown, and that whites of a higher economic class are coming into an area of a lower economic class, if you agree with that general description.
It seems that perhaps it's inaccurate in terms of the people coming into the city are those who have money, necessarily, as opposed to just being white; is that right?
Yeah, I mean, the first step in any gentrification in its purist form is always going to be economic.
People - the idea that people are forced to move isn't that they're forced to move just because they're black.
It's because they're forced to move because they're black and they can't afford to live there.

If you own a house in a particular neighborhood, you've been there for a long time and you can afford to hold on to that house unless your taxes go up dramatically, which does happen in some cases, but unless that happens, you don't have to go anywhere.
The problem is that in many neighborhoods, the African-Americans who lived there for a long time were not owners, they were renters, and that's an economic problem.
So that when rents go up, they can't afford to stay there, and the person who traditionally has come behind them has generally been a white person that can afford to move in.
That's changing somewhat because a black person can, you know, in many instances can now afford to come in, but it's still a displacement on the basis of both race and economic status.
